abstract.text: Please cite this article as: Khan, M.Z.H., Hasan, M.R., Hossain, S.I., Ahommed, M.S., Daizy, M., Ultrasensitive detection of pathogenic viruses with electrochemical biosensor: State of the art, Biosensors and Bioelectronics (2020), doi: https://doi.Abstract 2 Last few decades, viruses are a real menace to human safety. Therefore, the rapid identification 3 of viruses should be one of the best ways to prevent an outbreak and important implications for 4 medical healthcare. The recent outbreak of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) is an infectious 5 disease caused by a newly discovered coronavirus which belongs to the single-stranded, positive-6 strand RNA viruses. The pandemic dimension spread of COVID-19 poses a severe threat to the 7 health and lives of seven billion people worldwide. There is a growing urgency worldwide to 8 establish a point-of-care device for the rapid detection of COVID-19 to prevent subsequent 9 secondary spread. Therefore, the need for sensitive, selective, and rapid diagnostic devices plays 10 a vital role in selecting appropriate treatments and to prevent the epidemics. During the last 11 decade, electrochemical biosensors have emerged as reliable analytical devices and represent a 12 new promising tool for the detection of different pathogenic viruses. This review summarizes the 13 state of the art of different virus detection with currently available electrochemical detection 14 methods. Moreover, this review discusses different fabrication techniques, detection principles, 15 and applications of various virus biosensors. Future research also looks at the use of 16 electrochemical biosensors regarding a potential detection kit for the rapid identification of the 17 COVID-19.

body_text.text: Electrochemical biosensors are the biosensing devices containing electrochemical transducer that . In this review, we will 5 primarily focus on the recent development of impedance-based electrochemical methods, 6 immunosensors and DNA based electrochemical sensors for the detection of various viruses 7 recently reported. An electrochemical biosensor can monitor the activities of living cells or 8 enzymes by measuring the interaction between an analyte and the bioreceptor. In recent years, 9 electrochemical biosensors have shown great success in the fields of medical diagnostics due to 10 their unique properties and easy-to-use platform. Figure 1 represents the potential platform of 11 electrochemical biosensor for the detection of pathogenic viruses. pandemic. Therefore, it is a crying need to establish smart biosensors. Electrochemical 10 impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is considered as an efficient technique, which even detects any 11 tiny changes that occur at the solution-electrode interface. Hence, EIS is widely used to 12 characterize materials, and to monitor binding. Not only rapid response, low limit of detection 13 (LOD), and low cost but also real-time monitoring of the samples attracts extensive research 14 attention towards EIS method rather than using a traditional method like enzyme-linked 15 immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Another benefit of impedimetric methods is that the necessity of 16 enzymatic labels is not required to detect samples. On the other hand, EIS is a well-known 17 technique to investigate the electrical properties of nanomaterials. While interfaces tend to 18 expose to electronically conducting electrodes (Tlili et al., 2006) and (Hleli et al., 2006) . 19 Moreover, EIS has emerged as a powerful tool to quantify signals, because of its capability to 20 separate surface binding from the solution resistance. It is worthy to note that, in the case of antigen assay times could be reduced to a few seconds in serum by moving to an immittance 25 assay from capacitance. FIGREF1.text: Electrochemical biosensors commonly depend on the enzymatic catalysis reaction between the 26 immobilized biomolecules and the targeted analyte that produces electrons and affects the27 electrical properties of the solution (Kamikawa et al., 2010). Depending on the detection principle and application, electrochemical biosensor devices can be of potentiometric, 1 amperometric, conductometric, voltammetric, polarographic, impedimetric, capacitive, and 2 piezoelectric (Silva et al., 2014). Moreover, depending on the biological element incorporated, 3 different types of electrochemical biosensors are constructed, such as immunosensors, DNA 4 sensors or microbial sensors (Krejcova et al., 2013; Liu et al., 2011)

FIGREF2.text: Potential period of decades, viruses such as DENV, Avian influenza virus (AIV), Hepatitis virus, 6 ZIKV, Enterovirus, HPV, Chikungunya virus (CHIKV), Rabies virus (RABV), Human 7 norovirus, Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), HIV, and Coronavirus cause outbreak of infectious 8 diseases. Fast spreading and fatalities by these viruses lead to either a global epidemic or 9

FIGREF4.text: (Santos et al., 2018). Nguyen et al. used serotype 2 (Denv2) as an analyte in the EIS system and explored that resistance and 1 capacitance are effective to detect Denv2. The monitoring of capacitive signals plays a 2 significant role in order to develop biosensors (Nguyen et al., 2012). Previously, Cheng et al. 3 developed an electrochemical membrane-based nano biosensor, which showed a specific 4 response of the nano biosensor towards DENV rather than flaviviruses and nonflaviviruses. The 5 decrease in normalized nano biosensor signal response {1−(Ivirus/Ivirus=0)} toward DENV-2 is 6 ∼2.5 times higher than the other nonspecific viruses according to Fig. 2F. Signal response 7 {1−(Ivirus/Ivirus=0)} toward three different viruses was investigated. Where Ivirus depicts 8 signal response after the virus adopts from 102 pfu mL −1 solution. On the other hand, Ivirus=0 9 refers to the signal response of the same nano biosensor after 30 min exposure to antibody and 10 BSA immobilized virus-free medium (Cheng et al., 2012). In another interesting study, Tung et 11 al., exemplified electrochemical biosensor for confirming of weak interaction between DENV 12 and its receptor (C-type lectic domain family 5, member A (CLEC5A)). Anodic aluminum oxide 13 (AAO) substrate modified with gold nanoparticles (AuNps) was used to immobilize CLEC5A 14 followed by specific pre-treatments. The hybridization interaction between CLEC5A-DV was 15 intensively investigated by EIS. (Tung et al., 2014).

CNPs provide a large specific surface area for JEV 21 antibody immobilization. Which improves electron transfer efficiency. In addition, the amino 22 group on the surface of CNPs enable the attachment of antibody (Lai et al., 2017). Later, AgNPs 23 was used to modify SPCE, and investigated by EIS analysis concerning JEV. Ag NPs modified 24 SPCE showed a smaller semi-circular diameter than pristine SPCE, due to quick electron transfer 25 kinetics of [Fe (CN) 6 ] 3-/4on the as modified sample. FIGREF11.text: Heo et al. postulated a label-free electrochemical method to detect the hepatitis B virus (HBV) 16 on the Au electrode surface based on immobilization strategy. The study indicates the 17 potentiality of commercialization of a point-of-care testing (POCT) tool for viral diagnosis (Heo 18 et al., 2012).

FIGREF14.text: in body serum and many other media (Luppa et al., 2001). 2 Immunosensors are mainly comprised of a bioreceptor and a transducer. A bioreceptor is used to 3 recognize the target antigen or antibody that converts the producing biological signal into the 4 desired signal by a transducer. It is an effective technique for the detection of pathogens because 5 antibodies are naturally bound with antigens to form an antigen-antibody complex which is the 6 main principle of immunosensor for detecting antibody or antigen (Pollap and Kochana, 2019).

FIGREF15.text: Four types of immunosensor can be categorized according to the transducer, e.g.,8 electrochemical, thermometric, optical and magnetic (Patris et al., 2016). In electrochemical 9 immunosensor, the biological signal is converted into an electrical signal when the antigen-10 antibody complex is formed (Yadav et al., 2019). Besides, electrochemical immunosensors 11 exhibit significant interest in clinical diagnostics (Gómez et al., 2010). Based on the transducing 12 mechanisms, electrochemical immunosensors can be performed as non-labeled or labeled 13 immunological biosensors (Oswald et al., 2000). Both types of immunosensors had been 14 successfully used for the detection of particular viruses. Different viruses like, Plum pox virus 15 (Jarocka et al., 2013), DENV (Darwish et al., 2015), Fig mosaic virus (Haji-Hashemi et al., 16 2019) etc. are detected by electrochemical immunosensor recently.

FIGREF16.text: labeled electrochemical immunosensors possess a very simple and low-cost technique19 because it requires easy sample preparation, not too long detection procedure and no need of20 secondary antibody compared to labeled technique (Mazloum-Ardakani et al., 2015). The 21 detection efficiency of label-free electrochemical immunosensors depends on the precise 22 alignment of antibodies during the immobilization of antibodies (Shen et al., 2015). There are 23 various immobilization techniques of antibodies, such as straight adsorption on the electrode 24 surface, magnetic beads (MBs) or polymer matrices, SAMs, etc., that can be used. Among these 25 techniques, SAMs of alkanethiols are widely applied techniques because this technique provides 26 an easy way to produce strong covalent bonds, controlled arrangement, ultrathin, oriented and 27 ordered monolayer on the surface of the electrode (Haji-Hashemi et al., 2017). Monolayers of 28 metals like gold, silver with the sulfur compound are able to give a proper immobilization of 29 biomolecule. In the fabrication of electrochemical biosensor, SAMs functionalized carboxylic-antibodies group with succinimide and carbodiimide are also widely used (Chinnadayyala et al., 1 2019). Several reports have been made for the label-free detection of the antibody-antigen 2 complex by using electrochemical immunosensors. Among them, some applications have been 3 discussed in this review paper.Recently, an electrochemical immunosensor has been developed for the detection of highly6 pathogenic coronavirus associated with the MERS-CoV (Layqah and Eissa, 2019). Many serious 7 respiratory illnesses even death of human-caused by this coronavirus. In this work, carbon array 8 electrodes were fabricated with AuNPs electrodeposition to increase the sensitivity of the sensor.

FIGREF19.text: illustrates the immunosensor preparation for the detection of MERS-CoV. The SEM images for 11 the carbon array electrode surface modified with 20 CV scans and 30 CV scans at various 12 magnifications were presented in Fig. 4B. SEM image shows the homogenous layer of spherical 13 gold particles onto the electrode surface with an average of 50 nm diameter was obtained for 20 14 CV scans. The stepwise modification of the antigen modified electrodes was characterized by 15 square wave voltammetry (SWV) as shown in Fig. 4C. This immunosensor showed a LOD of 16 1.0 pg mL −1 and a satisfying recovery percentage. The proposed sensor also exhibited high 17 selectivity against Influenza A and B.

FIGREF20.text: sensitive as well as selective label-free electrochemical immunosensors for the 20 detection of Fig mosaic virus (FMV) has been developed with a LOD of 0.03 nM (Haji-Hashemi 21 et al., 2019). In this paper, a polyclonal antiserum (anti-FMV) against the virus nucleocapsid was 22 immobilized at the surface of the gold electrode modified with 11-mercaptoundecanoic acid 23 (MUA) and 3-mercapto propionic acid (MPA) through carbodiimide coupling reaction.24 Differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) was performed in ferri/ferrocyanide solution to evaluate 25 the electrochemical detection of FMV.

FIGREF22.text: Ning et al. have designed a highly sensitive sandwich-type electrochemical 13 immunosensor for the detection of avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J) (Ning et al., 2019).

FIGREF23.text: Avian leukosis virus is an endogenous retroviral pathogen that can cause the tumor, cancer etc.15 in poultry, doves, birds and mammals. Infections with avian leukosis virus caused huge financial losses to the poultry industry since the early of the 20th century. Although humans are not 1 directly infected by this virus, it can pass into humans because the commercially available 2 chicken and eggs carry this virus (Johnson, 1994). Authors have developed the sensor using a 3 perylene-3,4,9,10-tetracarboxylic acid functional graphene nanocomposite (GR-PTCA) as the 4 sensor platform and a ꞵ-cyclodextrin-nanogold-ferrocene (ꞵ-CD-AuNP-Fc) host-guest 5 complex as the label. The fabrication of the immunosensor is depicted in Fig. 5A. Firstly, ꞵ-CD 6 was directly immobilized on the secondary antibody (Ab 2 ) through covalent bonding and then 6-7 ferrocenylhexanethiol functionalized Au NPs (AuNP-Fc) were induced via host-guest 8 interactions. In this work, AuNPs decorated with 6-ferrocenylhexanethiol to increase the signal 9 of immunosensor. Fig. 5B represents a TEM image of the Fc-AuNP composite. The diameter of 10 the Au NPs used to prepare the composite was near to the Fc-AuNP (13 ± 3 nm). DVP response 11 was used to characterize the electrochemical signal of the modified electrodes as shown in Fig. 12 5C. DPV response of Ab1/GR-PTCA/GCE (curve a) and ALV-J/BSA/Ab1/GR-PTCA/GCE 13 (curve b) exhibited negligible electrochemical response which indicates the biomolecules and 14 GR-PTCA both are not electroactive. On the other hand, ALV-J/BSA/Ab1/GR-PTCA/GCE 15 (curve c) exhibited a strong electrochemical response at the time of introducing to the electrode 16 of Fc-AuNP-b-CD labeled Ab 2. A linear concentration of ALV-J, ranging from 10 2.0 to 10 4.0

FIGREF26.text: 2020, Xiang et al. reported two different immunoassays ELISA and colloidal gold-2 immunochromatographic assay (GICA)) which are simple, fast, easy, and clinically adaptable 3 for novel coronavirus COVID-19 diagnosis. They reported that a combination of ELISA IgM 4 and ELISA IgG produced detection sensitivity of 87.3% (55/63) whereas merged GICA IgM and 5 GICA IgG produced 82.4% (75/91). Notably, both kits showed a negative response against 6 controls (healthy samples) with 100% specificity (Xiang et al., 2020). Additionally, Li and his 7 team have reported a rapid and POC adoptable literal flow immunosensor which can diagnose 8 both immunoglobulin M (IgM) and IgG antibodies simultaneously against COVID-19 in 9 human's blood within 15 minutes (Li et al., 2020). The prescribed device was designed and 10 manufactured by Jiangsu Medomics Medical Technologies, China, which was investigated for 11 clinical validation and showed sensitivity and selectivity of 86.7% and 90.6% respectively 12 against 397 positive and 127 negative PCR confirmed patients. They also concluded that IgM-13 IgG combined assay can produce better performance over only of their single choice (Li et al., 14 2020

FIGREF27.text: transformed readable signal from generated hybridization, and a processor to show 3 the output. DNA based biosensors become the most efficient applicant in gene demonstration 4 with sequencing diagnostic behavior. It exceeds the barrier of sampling size & synthesis 5 complications (Stoughton, 2005). DNA biosensors are used in various ways to point out 6 nucleotide sequences. Compared to traditional hybridization assessment, DNA biosensors 7 provide rapid homo and bacterial nucleic acid information which broaden molecular diagnostics 8 by capturing analyte and readout accurate biological responses. The targeted amount and 9 hybridization intensity is the basis of a DNA based biosensors (Beattie et al., 1995). In the main, 10 single-strand DNA (ssDNA) along with target (nucleic acid) provides speedy DNA sequence 11 detection which makes it a considerate sensing element in medical diagnosis (Wang et al., 2011) 12 as well as in the food industry and environmental analysis by measuring differential 13 hybridization sensing from DNA probes and compatible sDNA. Due to all these features, it has 14 been viewed more seriously in the area of research. Different types of DNA based biosensors 15 like Electrochemical (Sun et al., 1998), Strip type (Glynou et al., 2003), Surface Plasmon 16 Resonance (SPR) type (Wang et al., 2004), Optical (Minunni et al., 2005), Quantum dot-based 17 (Kokkinos et al., 2015) biosensors have been introduced by many researchers in the field of al. designed an electrochemical DNA sensor by anthraquinone-labeled peptide 21 nucleic acid probe (AQ-PNA) using an inkjet printing technique for the determination of HPV-22 16 (Teengam et al., 2017). They electrostatically immobilized the DNA probe on graphene-23 polyaniline (G-PANI) modified electrode as shown in Fig. 6A. Peptide nucleic acid (PNA) with 24 repeating N-(2-aminoethyl)-glycine units provide strong affinity & higher specificity for target 25 DNA sequences. EIS & SWV confirm the AQ-PNA immobilization & hybridization (Fig. 6B) of 26 target DNA HPV-16 with a linear range between 10 -200 nM & gave a LOD of 2.3 nM. As 27 shown in Fig. 6C, seven gold electrode assembly was attached to the screen-printed Ag/AgCl 28 reference electrode which allows thiolated hairpin-DNA probes sequentially onto the sensing 29surface. The multi-electrode array has an advantageous property of good reproducibility. The hybridization process was monitored by SWV(Fig. 6D)showing higher peak currents with the 1 immobilized condition. Optimum accumulation time for methylene blue indicator was observed 2 (5 min) for high reproducibility. Excluding cross-interference for multiplexed DNA sequence3 determination, this biosensor shows linear current over ranges from 20 to 100 nM for HIV-1 and 4 HIV-2 with the same detection limit of 0.1 nm (S/N = 3). Furthermore, Cao et al. used the 5 piezotronic effect of ZnO NPs nanowire template to design a sensitive biosensor for the detection 6 of HIV. The ZnO nanowire provided an in-situ selective DNA detection of HIV (Cao et al., a PGE based biosensor was found to be effective to diagnose both influenza A and 9 influenza B in PCR amplified samples with detection limits of 35 nM and 21 nM respectively. 10 DPV technique was utilized to monitor real-time hybridization between the probe and target 11 DNA in the presence of acetate buffer solution as an electrolyte (Subak and Ozkan-Ariksoysal, 12 2018). Later, many research groups have reported different Nps modified electrode-based 13 biosensors focusing on improvement in the diagnosis process for several viruses.

FIGREF28.text: (A) Schematic illustration of electrode modification with G-PANI. (B) immobilization and 1 hybridization procedures of target DNA. (C) Cross-interference assays of the biosensor array for HIV-1 2 and HIV-2 detection. (D) Simultaneous detection of the biosensor array in the 100 μL of electrolyte 3 buffer solution (CH1∼CH3 with sample solution & CH4∼CH6 in immobilized condition). (Teengam et 4 al., 2017, Zhang et al.virus (HBV) becomes a major infectious disease that leads to liver failure or progress 8 to liver cirrhosis. Based on the need to early diagnose this disease, Meric et al. developed 9 electrochemical DNA biosensors for voltammetry detection of the DNA sequence of HBV 10 (Meric et al., 2002). They targeted the immobilized oligonucleotide (21-or 24-mer single strand) 11and hybridized on the carbon paste electrode (CPE). After that, the target sequence for infection12 diseases was determined from hybridized and probe modified CPE by square wave voltammetry13    SWV using methylene blue as a hybridization indicator with PCR amplification of real sample.14 In 2008, Hassen et al. presented another DNA biosensor based on streptavidin functionalized 15 magnetic nanoparticles for HBV detection by using EIS electrochemical impedance spectroscopy 16 strategy (Hassen et al., 2008). Firstly, they modified the Au electrode with biotin following 17 functionalized magnetic nanoparticles (biotin-streptavidin) and & immobilized DNA probes 18 using 300 mT magnet. Magnetic particles enhanced specific cell identification sensitivity. They 19 visualize & characterize nanoparticle layer before detection by Atomic force microscopy (AFM) 20 & Cyclic voltammetry. After investigating hybridization by non-faradic impedance spectroscopy 21 for different HBV DNA target concentrations they found excellent immobilization, which allows 22 them to detect 50 picomoles of HBV DNA on a sample of 20 µL without PCR amplification. 23 Further, an electrochemical DNA biosensor was developed to detect HBV with high conductive 24 gold nanorods (GNRs) (Shakoori et al., 2015). They used GNRs except for other emerging 25 nanoparticles like colloidal gold (Cai et al., 2001, Zhang et al., 2004) to increase surface area. 26 They placed GNRs on a modified 1,6-hexanedithiol (HDT) electrode and used [Co(phen) 3 ] 3+ as 27 an indicator to study the immobilization of different DNA sequences. After characterization, they 28 found good specificity with LOD of 2.0×10 -12 mol/L in a linear range from 1.0×10 -12 mol/L to 29 10.0×10 -6 mol/L for target DNA. Additionally, L. Ahangar and M. Mehrgardi in 2017 have 30 reported an DNA-based biosensor where SiO 2 electrode was modified with a nano-porous layer of gold (working electrode) and ssDNA probe were covalently immobilized to trace 1 complementary target element characteristic of HBV. The device was found linearly dynamic 2 and sensitive in the range of 0.4 to 10 nmol of altered DNA showing reliable reproducibility 3 confirmed by EIS and DPV (Ahangar and Mehrgardi, 2017).

FIGREF29.text: a novel electrochemical based biosensor for the detection of deadly EV-DNA had been6 successfully developed (Ilkhani and Farhad, 2018). In this work, the DNA biosensor was7 fabricated using a thiolated DNA capture probe sequence immobilized onto the Au surface of 8 screen-printed electrodes functionalized with thiolated single strand capture probe DNA (1µM). 9 It was used to capture biotinylated target sDNA (0.5M) and provides maximum hybridization in 10 60 min. The biotinylated target sDNA was labeled with a streptavidin-alkaline phosphatase 11 conjugate for electrochemical detection of the enzymatic product. The hybridization process on 12 the electrode was performed by the EIS and differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) methods. This 13 fabricated electrochemical DNA biosensor showed a low detection limit of 4.7 nM using the 14 standard deviation of blank solution for EBV complementary strand.

FIGREF30.text: al. have fabricated an electrochemical nanoporous membrane-based DNA biosensor for 17 DENV RNA detection by the immobilization of aminated DNA probes onto the alumina channel 18 walls, which improves the sensitivity of the sensor (Rai et al., 2012). The electrochemical 19 anodization was used to imprint alumina nanoporous membrane-like structure over the platinum 20 wire electrode. DNA capture probe sequence was immobilized on the electrode and hybridized 21 with complementary target DNA for the fabrication of DENV RNA -sensing devices. Later, 22 Oliveira et al. have developed graphite-based probe DNA specific biosensor to diagnose DENV3 23 serotype in human serum having LOD of 3.09 nM (Oliveira et al., 2015). A silicon nanowire-24 based biosensor was proposed by Nuzaihan et al. for detection of the target DNA sequence of 25 DENV with LOD ∼2.0 fM and sensitivity 45.0 μ AM −1 was achieved (Nuzaihan et al., 2016). In 26 another work, Odeh et al. have reported an amperometry biosensor for DENV2 serotype 27 detection with LOD of 17 nM. The sensor is comprised of an immobilized dengue-specific DNA 28 probe on Cu 2 CdSnS 4 quaternary alloy nanostructures deposited on an oxygen-etched silicon 29 substrate (O 2 /Si) (Odeh et al., 2017). Lee et al. reported a sensing platform for norovirus detection by using multi functionalized 1 carbon nanotubes (Lee et al., 2018). They fabricated the target DNA probe with Au/MNP-CNTs 2 which is magnetically aligned on Pt-integrated electrode (PtIDE). A carbon chain (C6) based 3 spacer was employed in the hybridization process. Under the magnetic field, nanomaterials can 4 spread out well on the PtIDE electrode and enhanced sensing performance. Compared to other 5 non-aligned platforms this method shows increased sensing behavior with different 6 concentrations of target DNA (1 pM to 10 nM) and confirmed the LOD around 8.8 pM. They 7 also performed the selectivity test on influenza and ZKV virus DNA but among them, norovirus 8 DNA shows an excellent response. 9 Recently, a promising DNA-based biosensor incorporated with silsesquioxane-functionalized 10 gold nanoparticles (AuNPs-SiPy) modified glassy carbon electrode (oxidized) was introduced 11 and showed selective performance for early-stage ZIKV diagnosis with LOD of 0.82 pM within 12 2 hours (Steinmetz et al., 2019). Device performance was afterword intensely investigated by 13 CV, EIS and AFM analysis which confirmed selective detection of ZIKV. The prescribed 14biosensor was also found stable and reusable after each use and performance restored around 15 98.0% of its initial response after 90 days.

FIGREF31.text: Sun et al., in 2008 have reported a biosensor to detect cauliflower mosaic virus (CaMV) with 17 LOD of 4.38 × 10 -12 mol/L (3r) (Sun et al., 2008). In this method, target sequence ssDNA of 18 CaMV was covalently immobilized on the surface of the mercaptoacetic acid-modified self-19 assembled Au electrode. On the other hand, HNO 3 was used to dissolve lead sulfide (PbS) NPs 20 capped probe oligonucleotide sequence (CaMV 35 S). Afterword three electrodes systems 21 emerged inside and a sensitive differential pulse anodic stripping voltammetry method applied to 22 observe hybridization between target ssDNA and complementary probe ssDNA. Table 3 shows 23 the analytical performance of DNA based electrochemical biosensors for the detection of 24 different viruses.

FIGREF34.text: COVID-19 is an RNA virus and having single-strand RNA instead of ssDNA. By utilizing the 3 corresponding immobilization of the single-stranded DNA probe nucleotide on to the biosensor,4 a specific viral RNA sequence of COVID-19 can be detected. During the outbreak period, 5 researchers have already reported different detection strategies focusing on DNA−RNA 6 hybridization. Recently, Qiu et al., proposed a dual-functional plasmonic photothermal biosensor 7 for highly sensitive and accurate COVID-19 detection by testing on SARS-CoV (Qiu et al., 8 2020). They made a DNA probe with functionalized gold nanoisland (AuNI) chips to match 9 specific viral RNA sequences through nucleic acid hybridization. Combining the plasmonic 10 photothermal (PPT) effect and localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) sensing transduction 11 significantly enhances the sensing stability, sensitivity, and reliability. Moreover, DNA 12 hybridization can be considered as a portable electrochemical sensor for point mutation detection 13 of COVID-19-specific viral RNA/cDNA (Tripathy and Singh, 2020). Future studies on the 14 specific binding configuration of ssDNA on several viruses genomes could help to reduce the 15 dependency of PCR-based tests and can be used to prevent future pandemics.

FIGREF35.text: Concluding remarks and Future prospects19 Since the coronavirus COVID-19 pandemic is the defining global health crisis of the present 20 time and the greatest challenge the world is facing now, the development of rapid and high-21 sensitivity assays for its detection has tremendous importance. During past decades, extensive22 investigation has been conducted for the sensitive detection of viruses and it is clear from the 23 literature discussed in this review that biosensing methodologies have achieved huge 24 improvements for virus detection in terms of selectivity, sensitivity, specificity, and response 25 time. Herein, we have critically discussed different electrochemical biosensors to detect 26 pathogenic viruses and their modification methods as well. Moreover, the details of immobilization procedures, electrochemical response mechanism and their applications have 1 been also mentioned.2Although biosensor technologies are highly promising, they present many challenges in order to 3 move from the bench to their use in the point of care. The immobilization method of the 4 concerned nanomaterials and biological elements is critical to minimize the risk of mistakes and 5 errors in virus detection. Another important issue is the lifetime of the assay, which is sometimes6

TABREF1.text: ). Moreover, Zhao et al. in 2020 have revealed another immunosensor based on ELISA to 15 detect total antibodies (Ab), IgM and IgG against COVID-19 from human serum. They 16 diagnosed plasma of 173 patients with seroconversion rate for Ab, IgM and IgG was 93.1%, 82.7% and 64.7%, respectively (Zhao et al., 2020). The principle of Ab diagnosis is based on 18 double-antigens sandwich immunoassay (Ab-ELISA) whereas IgM and IgG detection methods 19were based on IgM μ-chain capture method (IgM-ELISA) and recombinant nucleoprotein respectively.
